title: At close of business on 29 April 2020, will the upper limit of the Federal Reserve's target range for the federal funds rate be lower, the same, or higher than it was at close of business on 18 March 2020?
preds: COVID19 - not the moment to increase rates
Final forecast.  Still going with CME FedWatch.
I am basically still going with the CME FedWatch consensus
I'm just going with the CME Fed Watch at this point.

I still find it difficult to imagine the Fed going to negative rates.  True, interest rates on short-term bills turned negative in late-March, and even though they've inched back up, a certain psychological barrier has possibly been broken. But I see the Fed as having too many other options at this point, and there seems to be a pause in pessimism just now.  That pause could certainly be short-lived, but I think negative rates will be akin to the last stand at the Alamo, and it doesn't seem as though we're there (yet).  And of course raising rates is out of the question.

Due to the fact that we are currently heading into a recession. This Fed is incompetent.  I predicted  A).  That the Fed didnt know what was going on, and that they would be forced to react to market conditions rather than cut proactively.  I was correct.  B).  When they cut originally - I said they were incompetent.  They announced an action by itself, when what they *needed* to do was announce cooredinated policy with other G20.     As a result of that, I predicted they would have to cut again, before April 20.  C.  This cut - is both incompetent and *insane*.  They have completely panicked and are now contributing to market meltdown, rather than stability.   While the actions in the repo markets were necessary, dropping interests rates to the floor was *wrong*.   We have now reached the limits of what fed policy can realistically hope to accomplish.  D.  I have no idea how to parse the fed at this point.  E.  Back in December, I said that rates would have to go to zero, or close to zero.   Fundamentally, the only way to overcome our debt over hang is to grow our way out of it.   And zero interest is the only way to do  that.  One of the interesting  phenomenon going on is that corporate profits are declining - and companies are using lots of credit to buy stocks.   More or less, corporate share buybacks are soppig up liquidity. Earnings are going down, but earnings per share are going up, because capital is being sopped up in buying up shares.  We are rearranging the chairs on the titanic, again.  Locking up capital (non-productively) in shares, means that ever increasing amounts of profits will be spent paying back debt.  Corporations are becoming top heavy. For an example of why - look at the same corporations today.  Can they sell F.their stocks into a down market?  No. F.  Don't follow me at 100% same.    I am contemplating 'lower'.

The Fed has gone to something near the limit of what it can do in terms of interest rates. Going higher is impossible because the goal is to stimulate spending. Indeed, the last decade of low rates has only been possible because the fragility of the post-2008 recession has been so evident that hiking interest rates significantly was off the table. I think near-zero or zero rates are here for the long-term. Within the scope of the question, I do not see the rate going higher.  Could it go lower? Possibly, but against that is the market slump today: the Fed is in that unenviable position in which actions taken to stimulate the economy simply add to the panic. At this point, any Fed action will be action for the sake of action, but recovery demands a massive, massive shock-and-awe stimulus package as well as a plan to deal with Covid-19 that is credible. Clearly, neither markets nor businesses at large believe that Covid-19 is going away anytime soon. Furthermore, the kind of anti-Covid-19 measures that have worked in China, South Korea, Taiwan, Singapore, Hong Kong, etc, are measures that the UK and US are unwilling to undertake, I suspect from fear of the disruptions it would cause and the cost such measures would involve.  I suspect this is a 2-year Covid-crisis and fresh thinking is needed. Fiddling with rates is no longer effective. It's also interesting to note that the Fed announcement stated that the Fed would hold rates at the new levels “until it is confident that the economy has weathered recent events and is on track to achieve its maximum employment and price stability goals" (https://www.federalreserve.gov/monetarypolicy/files/monetary20200315a1.pdf). I think the appetite to get to zero is limited and the benefit is marginal. It would merely communicate a belief on the part of the Fed that they believed today's measures had failed.

Fed rates were just cut to zero. There is a small possibility of recovery, hence the small "Higher" percentage, but it is very unlikely to happen due to 2nd wave of Covid. It is also unlikely that the Fed rate move will have much impact on the economy, hence a small chance of further lowering rates in an attempt to limit downside. However, I think there is very little appetite for negative interest rates in the US.
I don't believe the fed will be eager to drop the rates further after they cut it to zero.
They moved it again already.  Before 18 March! So those who said lower were sort of correct in thinking  but not as the q was written (!!)

I was at essentially 100%, but gave 35% to the "same" bucket because I thought an emergency cut sooner was possible, obviating the need for a cut during the period of the question. Well, now that's happened so adjusting my odds down.

The Federal Reserve is expected to cut its rates to the 0-0.25 band during their March meetings [1]. There is talk of the Federal Reserve possibly taking the rate into negative territory with futures markets predicting a 26% probability of this occurring by the end of December 2020 [2]. This has never happened in the history of the Federal Reserve and seems unlikely to happen both in the near future and in the longer term. There would need to be a drastic change in the status of the economy for the fed to really consider negative interest rates, in my personal assessment. EDIT - Jerome Powell just made a statement that the Federal Reserve doesn't see negative interest rates as "appropriate policy" for the United States [4]. This currently means the Federal Reserve is unwilling to drop their federal fund rates below the current rate band of 0-0.25. Many large businesses have decided to shut their doors for the next 2-6 weeks. Due to a lack of economic data that will be collected between the end of March and 28-29 April, it is unlikely that the  Federal Fund rate will be taken into negative territory. It is more likely that the Federal Reserve will re-institute Quantitative Easing measures it last used in 2008, such as guaranteeing to keep the rate at 0% and purchasing more bonds [3]. However, many individuals are questioning whether there is much more the Federal Reserve can do to stabilize the economy without decisive action taken by the Federal Government [3]. I assess that the Federal Reserve will cut the federal fund interest rate to the 0-0.25 band during their March meeting (among other measures) and will re-affirm their commitment to the 0 rate band in the April meeting. Thus, I assess a 100% probability that at the close of business on 29 April 2020, the upper limit of the Federal Reserve's target range for the federal funds rate will be the same as it was at the close of business on 18 March 2020: 0-0.25. Please point out/correct any incorrect statements/analysis/assumptions I have made. [1] https://www.cnbc.com/2020/03/13/fed-increasingly-expected-to-cut-interest-rates-to-zero-next-week.html
[2] https://www.nytimes.com/reuters/2020/03/12/business/12reuters-health-coronavirus-rates-options.html
[3] https://finance.yahoo.com/news/fed-having-leisurely-rethink-then-110000864.html
[4] https://www.cnbc.com/2020/03/15/powell-says-the-fed-doesnt-see-negative-rates-as-appropriate-policy-for-the-united-states.html

The Federal Reserve's decision will be largely based on how severe COVID-19 is in the USA. Federal Fund rates were cut to 1.25-1% on March 3rd in an Emergency move to help the economy hurt by COVID-19. At the FOMC meeting on March 18th, rates are expected to be cut again. The question is, will rates be further cut at the April FOMC meeting? South Korea can be used as a case study to analyze how a democratic, wealthy country deals with COVID-19. On February 22 South Korea recorded its first day of >200 daily infections. It took until March 9th, 17 days, for daily infections to fall under 200 cases. The US recorded its first day with >200 daily infections on March 9th. Considering the US is struggling to produce test kits and have tested only 4,385 people (0.001% of the population) according to the Atlantic as of March 9th. South Korea is testing 15,000 people a day for a total of around 200,000 (almost .5% of the population). I expect that it takes the US longer than 17 days to reduce new cases under 200 meaning that the rapid spread COVID-19 will continue into April in the US. This will hurt the economy and prompt the Fed to cut rates again. US President Donal Trump has historically pressured the Fed to cut rates to help the economy and in an election year, this pressure will only increase.  https://www.worldometers.info/world-population/us-population/
https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2020/03/coronavirus-testing-numbers/607714/
https://www.cnn.com/2020/03/09/asia/south-korea-coronavirus-intl-hnk/index.html
https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/coronavirus-us-cases.html
https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/country/south-korea/
https://tradingeconomics.com/united-states/interest-rate

The Fed's decision will be mainly driven by the economic impact of coronavirus. Given the current measures for containment, I expect the number of cases will continue growing exponentially. As a result, between March 18 and April 29, we will see significant disruption of economic activity. Fed will respond to the real-time economic data by cutting rates. Moreover, Trump keeps pushing Fed to cut rates aggressively. However, there are several scenarios where Fed could keep the interest rate unchanged: (1) The number of cases increases at a lower speed than expected, and therefore results in less significant impact on the economy; (2) The inflation rate rises due to shortage of supply; (3) Fed may worry they may not have sufficient monetary policy space if the rate is cut too quickly.

If they statement is more cautious, the holds will continue, but if it is more aggressive the another cut in April becomes all the more likely.

Note to myself to capture my thinking:  I'm firmly in the camp that this is going to create a big impact on the US economy. However it's interesting to consider how that will translate to a response by the FMOC. It may not be lower interest rates. So my 35% "Same" estimate is almost entirely due to questions about timing and whether rate cuts are the tool they choose to use in April. One interesting aspect of this: 
https://www.marketwatch.com/story/why-a-supply-shock-is-biggest-stock-market-worry-as-viral-outbreak-continues-2020-02-25 In a nutshell: a demand shock can be addressed with monetary or fiscal policy. However supply shocks can cause a spike in inflation and are not easily managed with monetary and fiscal policy. The macro picture will depend on the composite of a bunch of individual but connected markets (plastics, glass, electronic components, cars, phones, etc). If demand drops more than supply, which seems possible over the next few months, then prices could spike for individual items and it's unclear to me what the aggregate effect would be. But one possibility is higher inflation.  A spike in inflation that was believed to be short term (<1 year) would mean:
1) suddenly negative short-term real interest rates, putting downward pressure on short term bill prices / upward pressure on nominal rates
2) lower long-term interest rates
3) risks to those US financial institutions that aren't prepared for that combination of factors => systemic risks to other banks I guess in that situation the Fed would need to provide direct funding to US institutions to keep them onsides with their liquidity and capital ratio limits. That would hammer the financial sector of the stock market. 
The supply and demand shocks would hammer many brick and mortar businesses. 
Travel, leisure and hospitality are already hammered but with lots more room to drop  That could all happen pretty fast (2-3 months) if this supply disruption continues. It would appear that:
1) life is on track to return to the new normal in China; however, when they start relaxing their controls will COVID come raging back? If so then we have a problem. We should get early indications on that in the coming weeks and I think that's part of why the market reacted so harshly to a relatively minor uptick in Wuhan cases today;
2) Outside of China supply disruption hasn't really kicked in yet. My guess is that it will.  Scheduled FOMC meetings

Why would the Fed raise rates? Because the economy is heating too quickly. This does not seem to be the case as (a) GDP growth is positive but moderate, and (b) inflation is holding steady despite great employment figures. Furthermore, after the pounding the Fed took last year from Trump when they raised rates, and with Trump recently saying at Davos that he could get used to negative rates, it's just hard to imagine the Fed raising them except under the most dire of circumstances. Why would the Fed lower rates? Because economic growth is slowing significantly. This does not seem to be at all the case. The 800 pound gorilla of the GDP is consumer spending, and -- as Tim Duy pointed out in his most recent "Fed Watch" blog post -- consumer spending is anything but weak. Both trains of thought have been supported over the past several weeks when 10 Fed governors and regional Presidents indicated that they expect rates to remain where they are for the foreseeable future. That said, three months is a long time in this domain, and a lot can happen.  So I will add a bit more margin than I did with the March forecast.

I am underweighting the target rate moving higher - this is because it has been on a downward trajectory since early Q3 2019, and the fed is likely to want to hedge against election-related uncertainty.
Economy will show signs of slowing

There are some indicators suggestive of a global downturn and possible looming US recession. The US has been experiencing an approximate 10 year expansion - the longest in its history. Yet, WorldBank data since 1961 suggests expansions historically last between 1-4 years before another contraction. The recent downturn in the November jobs report (down 561,000, lowest since Feb '18), contractions in the retail, construction, and manufacturing markets, financial challenges with major corporations like Boeing and General Electric, and concerns over the long-term stability of the US-China phase I trade deal - in an ongoing trade war - there is a strong probability the US economy may contract in the next 6-12 months despite a strong stock market. Since April 2019 the Fed lowered the interest rate from 2.41% to 1.54% - three distinct drops in the last 6 months.  Though it has remained mostly flat since November. I believe they will hold to their last announcement that they do not anticipate making further adjustments for the foreseeable future.  However, if they do decide to move it, they will lower it to stimulate economic activity and offset recession-like activity.
I think it's likely that it will remain the same.

The Fed currently seems to be in a wait and see mode. “Higher” seems quite unlikely. The CME Fed Watch tool has it at 6%. I think that might be an overestimate. A rate increase would be justified if the economy begins to show signs of overheating. How likely is that? One argument is that election years induce uncertainty that lowers sentiment and investment. This recent article [1] argues that election years tend to be turbulent for the stockmarket. We are also coming out of a very strong 2019, which also raises the chances for some consolidation [1]. Another argument, for what it’s worth, is that if the Fed raised rates, it is quite possible that Trump will fire Powell. The extent to which Powell feels the need to steer clear of that are uncertain however. The chances of a lower rate seem higher but that will depend on future inflation data and unemployment data.  [1] “The Economist | Christmas bonus”

From 2017-2019, there have been 3-4 target changes per year out of around 7 meetings (I think). 
So the chance of change based on that reference class would be around 50%. 
In 2008 and 2005 there were 7-8 target changes, but I don't know if the schedule was the same. 
In 2015 and 2016 there was only one change per year. 
So 50% change seems a reasonable base rate.  From 2004-2006, all changes were increases. From 2007-2008, all changes were decreases. From 2015-2018, all changes were increases. In 2019, all changes were decreases.  There seems to be considerable 'momentum' in the direction of changes, suggesting decrease is much more likely than increase. In general when there has been a change in direction, there has usually been a gap of at least 2 months - so we should revisit this in Feb/March, and if there has been another recent decrease at that point an increase would be very unlikely indeed.  The current level is 1.50-1.75. Source: https://www.federalreserve.gov/monetarypolicy/openmarket.htm

FedWatch probabilities are 82% for same and 18% for lower. I think same is the base case for a couple reasons.
- by the April meeting, the Fed will finally be seeing the impacts of their 75bps cuts in 2019 and will probably want to wait to take further action
- I’m expecting data to remain solid on the jobs and consumer front, moderate to weak on the manufacturing front, and cautious on the business investment front. Main risk to this is global uncertainty pushing down business investment and forcing the Fed to act
- trade war quiets down after this most recent “non-deal” deal because both sides turn their attention towards the election Ultimately, my view is that future cuts will be more heavily-weighted towards the latter half of the year. My base case though is for a single cut. I do see a scenario that could force a hike, but the likelihood is low in my view
